articles.title: About this site
articles.description: Some additional details about the website
articles.contents:
About Me
Maxwell is a rising senior at Newton North High
School. He enjoys writing and playing the saxophone.
About the Project
My project, The Title of My Project, explores…
Goals
Goal One
Challenge One

Goal Two
‘“This is data science”’

Preceptor

Kane’s Free High School
Data Science Bootcamp

articles.title: Title of My Final Project
articles.description: This is where I will describe my final project.

articles.contents:
Title of My Final Project


Home
Core
About


Sources
 
▾


Source A
Source B


☰


  
    
      
        
        
        
      
      
    
    
      
  Home


  Core


  About


  
    Sources
     
    
  
  
      Source A
    
    
      Source B
    
  
      
  










heart2020 <- read_csv(file = "heart_2020_cleaned.csv")
## Rows: 319795 Columns: 18
## ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
## Delimiter: ","
## chr (14): HeartDisease, Smoking, AlcoholDrinking, Stroke, DiffWalking, Sex, ...
## dbl  (4): BMI, PhysicalHealth, MentalHealth, SleepTime
## 
## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
introplot <- heart2020 |>
  group_by(AgeCategory)|>
  summarize(PercentageofHD = mean(HeartDisease == "Yes")) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = AgeCategory, y = PercentageofHD)) +
   geom_smooth(method = "loess", formula = y ~ x) +
  geom_col(fill = "maroon", color = "black") +
 scale_x_discrete(breaks = c("18-24", "30-34", "40-44", "50-54", "60-64", "70-74", "80 or older")) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format()) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank()) +
  labs(title = "The Age Distribution of People With Heart Disease",
       subtitle = "Risk for Heart Problems Increases With Age",
       x = "Age",
       y = "Percentage Heart Disease") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.text = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
write_rds(introplot, "introplot.rds")

Title of My Final Project


Home
Core
About

    Sources

heart2020 <- read_csv(file = "heart_2020_cleaned.csv")
## Rows: 319795 Columns: 18
## ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
## Delimiter: ","
## chr (14): HeartDisease, Smoking, AlcoholDrinking, Stroke, DiffWalking, Sex, ...
## dbl  (4): BMI, PhysicalHealth, MentalHealth, SleepTime
## 
## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
heart2020 |>
slice_sample(n = 1000)
## # A tibble: 1,000 × 18
##    HeartDis…¹   BMI Smoking Alcoh…² Stroke Physi…³ Menta…⁴ DiffW…⁵ Sex   AgeCa…⁶
##    <chr>      <dbl> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>    <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr> <chr>  
##  1 No          40.7 No      No      No           0       0 No      Male  55-59  
##  2 No          25.4 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 45-49  
##  3 No          43.2 Yes     No      No           0       0 Yes     Fema… 65-69  
##  4 No          29.1 No      No      No          30      14 No      Fema… 65-69  
##  5 No          53.0 Yes     No      No           0      20 No      Fema… 25-29  
##  6 No          25.4 No      No      No          30      30 Yes     Fema… 18-24  
##  7 No          28.5 No      No      No           3       0 No      Male  70-74  
##  8 Yes         26.5 Yes     No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 55-59  
##  9 Yes         26.8 Yes     No      Yes         30      15 Yes     Fema… 60-64  
## 10 No          25.8 Yes     No      No          15      15 Yes     Male  45-49  
## # … with 990 more rows, 8 more variables: Race <chr>, Diabetic <chr>,
## #   PhysicalActivity <chr>, GenHealth <chr>, SleepTime <dbl>, Asthma <chr>,
## #   KidneyDisease <chr>, SkinCancer <chr>, and abbreviated variable names
## #   ¹​HeartDisease, ²​AlcoholDrinking, ³​PhysicalHealth, ⁴​MentalHealth,
## #   ⁵​DiffWalking, ⁶​AgeCategory
## # ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows, and `colnames()` to see all variable names
sample1000 <- heart2020 |>
  slice_sample(n = 1000)
healthplot <- sample1000 |>
  group_by(GenHealth, Sex) |>
  summarize(mean_BMI = mean(BMI), .groups = "drop") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = GenHealth, y = mean_BMI, fill = Sex)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge", color = "black") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("cornflowerblue", "lightpink")) +
  scale_x_discrete(limits = c("Poor", "Fair", "Good", "Very good", "Excellent")) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "The Average Body Mass Index in Five Categories of Health",
       subtitle = "Higher BMIs tend to result in worsened health",
       x = "General Health",
       y = "Average Body Mass Index (BMI)",
       fill = "Gender") +
      theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.text = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
write_rds(healthplot, "healthplot.rds")

Title of My Final Project


Home
Core
About


Sources
 
▾


Source A
Source B


☰


  
    
      
        
        
        
      
      
    
    
      
  Home


  Core


  About


  
    Sources
     
    
  
  
      Source A
    
    
      Source B
    
  
      
  










heart2020 <- read_csv(file = "heart_2020_cleaned.csv")
## Rows: 319795 Columns: 18
## ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
## Delimiter: ","
## chr (14): HeartDisease, Smoking, AlcoholDrinking, Stroke, DiffWalking, Sex, ...
## dbl  (4): BMI, PhysicalHealth, MentalHealth, SleepTime
## 
## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
heart2020
## # A tibble: 319,795 × 18
##    HeartDis…¹   BMI Smoking Alcoh…² Stroke Physi…³ Menta…⁴ DiffW…⁵ Sex   AgeCa…⁶
##    <chr>      <dbl> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>    <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr> <chr>  
##  1 No          16.6 Yes     No      No           3      30 No      Fema… 55-59  
##  2 No          20.3 No      No      Yes          0       0 No      Fema… 80 or …
##  3 No          26.6 Yes     No      No          20      30 No      Male  65-69  
##  4 No          24.2 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 75-79  
##  5 No          23.7 No      No      No          28       0 Yes     Fema… 40-44  
##  6 Yes         28.9 Yes     No      No           6       0 Yes     Fema… 75-79  
##  7 No          21.6 No      No      No          15       0 No      Fema… 70-74  
##  8 No          31.6 Yes     No      No           5       0 Yes     Fema… 80 or …
##  9 No          26.4 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 80 or …
## 10 No          40.7 No      No      No           0       0 Yes     Male  65-69  
## # … with 319,785 more rows, 8 more variables: Race <chr>, Diabetic <chr>,
## #   PhysicalActivity <chr>, GenHealth <chr>, SleepTime <dbl>, Asthma <chr>,
## #   KidneyDisease <chr>, SkinCancer <chr>, and abbreviated variable names
## #   ¹​HeartDisease, ²​AlcoholDrinking, ³​PhysicalHealth, ⁴​MentalHealth,
## #   ⁵​DiffWalking, ⁶​AgeCategory
## # ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows, and `colnames()` to see all variable names
smokeplot <- heart2020 |>
  mutate(Smoker_categorized = if_else(Smoking == "Yes", "Smokes", "Does Not Smoke")) |>
  select(Race, Smoker_categorized, HeartDisease, Diabetic) |>
  group_by(Race, Smoker_categorized, Diabetic) |> 
  summarize(Percent_HD = mean(HeartDisease == "Yes"), .groups = "drop") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = Race, y = Percent_HD, fill = Diabetic)) +
  coord_flip() +
  geom_col(color = "black") +
  facet_wrap(~Smoker_categorized) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format()) +
  theme_light() +
   theme(panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank()) +
  labs(title = "Comparison of the Percent of Smoking and Non-Smoking \nIndividuals from Each Race Who Have Heart Disease",
       subtitle = "Individuals with Diabetes are much more susceptible to heart issues",
       y = "Percent with Heart Disease in Each Race",
       x = "Race") +
    theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          plot.subtitle = element_text(face = "italic"),
          axis.text = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
write_rds(smokeplot, "smokeplot.rds")

articles.contents:
Distill is a publication format for scientific and technical writing,
native to the web.
Learn more about using Distill for R Markdown at https://rstudio.github.io/distill.

articles.title: Source A
articles.contents:
Source A was Primer.data. It was flawless. (Kane 2020) (Jones 2018)



Jones, Nora. 2018. “Distill for r Markdown.” Journal of
Data Science Software. https://doi.org/10.23915/distill.00010.


Kane, David. 2020. Primer.data.
